metadata.title: Pt nanoparticles entrapped in mesoporous metal–organic frameworks MIL-101 as an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-ketoesters
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Pt nanoparticles entrapped in mesoporous metal–organic frameworks MIL-101 as an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-ketoesters Huiyan Pan Xiaohong Li ⁎ Damin Zhang Yejun Guan Peng Wu Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, Department of Chemistry, East China Normal University, 3663 North Zhongshan Road, Shanghai 200062, China Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, Department of Chemistry, East China Normal University 3663 North Zhongshan Road Shanghai 200062 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 21 62238590; fax: +86 21 62238590. Graphical abstract Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was prepared via a facile impregnation method and was tested for the chiral hydrogenation of α-ketoesters after chirally modified with cinchona alkaloid. The powder XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, TEM, and CO chemisorption were employed to characterize the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. The Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was proved effective for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate and ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate after chirally modified with cinchonidine. Up to 4469h−1 TOF with 76.5% ee of (R)-(+)-ethyl lactate was obtained with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst in acetic acid. The fastest chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIl-101 catalyst took place in neat water with medium enantioselectivity. While for the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst, over 2000h−1 TOF with 76.8% ee value was achieved in a mixed solvent containing acetic acid and ethanol with an equal volume. Of particular note is that the Pt/MIl-101 catalyst could be reused at least four times without distinct loss in activity or enantioselectivity with addition of fresh chiral modifier each time in the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate. The catalytic performance of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was also compared for the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate with the commercial Pt/C and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts after modification with cinchona alkaloid. Keywords Pt nanoparticles MIL-101 Asymmetric hydrogenation Ethyl pyruvate Ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate 1 Introduction Recently, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted much attention because of their potential application as catalyst or as support for heterogeneous catalysts [1–3]. MOFs usually have the advantages of large specific surface area and pore volume, porosity, well-defined structure, chemical tenability, and flexibility [4,5]. Even though much endeavor has been put on synthesis of novel MOFs, only a few MOFs such as MOF-5, ZIF-8, Uio-66 and recently developed MIL series can be applied to catalysis [6–8]. Since Férey et al. firstly reported the synthesis of MIL-53 in 2002, MIL-100 and MIL-101 in 2005, a great deal of interests has been focused on these materials in gas storage and catalysis [9,10]. MIL-101 is a kind of MOFs with a complex structure: the connector consists of a chromium oxo trimer being connected to six other connectors through doubly deprotonated terephthalic acid linkers. The resulting tetrahedron is assembled into the so-called “super tetrahedrons” leading to two different cavities with pore dimensions of about 2.9 and 3.4nm and pore windows of 1.2–1.6nm (Scheme 1 ) [11]. Owing to large surface area, relatively high thermal stability, hydrothermal stability and acid–base resistance, MIL-101 has been used as catalyst directly in cyanosilylation of aldehydes and in selective oxidation of alkenes or alkanes [12–14]. The MIL-101 functionalized with amino group displayed good catalytic performance in condensation of benzaldehyde into trans-ethylcyanocinnamate [15]. Another focus was MIL-101 composites with phosphotungistic acid to catalyze H2O2-based alkene epoxidation and aldehyde–alcohol condensation [16,17]. Of particular note is that MIL-101 can support and disperse noble metal nanoparticles. For instance, Pd loaded onto MIL-101 catalyzed hydrogenation of styrene and ketones effectively and acted as an efficient catalyst for the water-mediated Suzuki–Miyaura and Ullmann coupling reactions of aryl chlorides [12,18,19]. Pd nanoparticles deposited on MIL-101 was efficient for one-step synthesis of methyl isobutyl ketone and for one-pot indole synthesis between 2-iodoaniline and phenylacetylene in water [20,21]. The Au/MIL-101 exhibited superior catalytic performance for selective oxidation of cyclohexane by molecular oxygen in the absence of solvent [22], and was proved efficient for liquid-phase aerobic oxidation of a wide range of alcohols and even effective for oxidation at ambient conditions in the absence of water or base by another research group [23]. Ultrafine Pt nanoparticles immobilized inside the pores of MIL-101 was active for catalytic reactions in all three phases: liquid-phase ammonia borane hydrolysis, solid-phase ammonia borane thermal dehydrogenation, and gas-phase CO oxidation [24]. The Pt/NH2-MIL-101(Al) containing phosphotungstic acid exhibited better CO oxidation activity and higher selectivity to CO2 than alumina supported Pt [25]. Alfa-functionalized chiral alcohols are very important in spices, medicines, and pesticides. Heterogeneous enantioselective hydrogenation of α-functionalized ketones is a process with practical values to obtain α-functionalized chiral alcohols. Since Orito et al. discovered the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-ketoesters with the cinchona alkaloid-Pt catalysts in the late 1970s [26–28], many scientists have been devoting themselves to extending the application of this system and to exploring new materials to support Pt nanoparticles [29–31]. To the best of our knowledge, Pt/Al2O3, Pt nanoparticles confined in carbon nanotubes, and Pt nanoparticles entrapped in Al2O3@SBA-15 composites are the best candidates for the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-functionalized ketones [32–35]. Nevertheless, there still existed some problems, such as peptization of alumina under acidic conditions for Pt/Al2O3 catalyst [36], and cumbersome preparations of carbon nanotubes and Al2O3@SBA-15 composites [35]. Encouraged by that Pt nanoparticles could be well dispersed and confined inside the pores of MIL-101 and have been proved active in some reactions, herein, we loaded Pt nanoparticles onto MIL-101 and investigated the catalytic performance for the enantioselective hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate (ETPY) and ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate (EOPB) after chirally modified with cinchona alkaloid (Scheme 2 ). The Pt/MIL-101 catalyst exhibited high activity with good enantioselectivity for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY and EOPB. Up to 4469h−1 TOF was obtained for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY with cinchonidine (CD)-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. It is worth noting that the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst can also be reused for several times without distinct loss in activity or enantioselectivity. The commercial Pt/C and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts were also applied for the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate after modification with cinchona alkaloid for comparison. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The MIL-101 was synthesized according to Ref. [10]. The 5wt.% Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was prepared via an impregnation method [37]. The MIL-101 was impregnated with an ethanolic solution containing H2PtCl6 and stirred for 4–6h. Then the mixture was evaporated to remove the excess ethanol, followed by drying at 373K overnight. Subsequently, the catalyst precursor was reduced in an aqueous solution of sodium formate at 368K for 2h and then washed by plenty of water to remove chlorine anion. Finally, the sample was dried at 373K overnight. 2.2 Characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE instrument using Cu Kα radiation. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms of samples were measured at 77K on a Quantachrome Autosorb-3B system, after the samples were evacuated at 473K for 10h. The BET specific surface area was calculated using adsorption data in the relative pressure range from 0.05 to 0.35. The pore size distribution curves were calculated from the analysis of the adsorption branch of the isotherm using the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) algorithm. The CO chemisorption of sample was measured at 308K on a Quantachrome CHEMBET-3000 pulse chemisorption analyzer after the samples were pretreated in a 5vol.% H2/95vol.% Ar flow at 503K for 2h. The degree of dispersion and the mean particle size (cubic model) were estimated from the measured CO uptake, assuming a cross-sectional area for a surface platinum atom of 8.0×10−20 m2 and a stoichiometric factor of one, using the nominal platinum concentrations. The morphology and particle size was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a Hitachi S-4800 microscope. The Pt particle size and dispersion was also measured with transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on an FEI Tecnai G2-TF30 microscope at an acceleration voltage of 300kV. The leached Pt amount was detected with a Thermo Elemental IRIS Intrepid II XSP inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES). 2.3 Catalytic tests For the asymmetric hydrogenation, 0.05g 5wt.% Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was pretreated under a hydrogen flow (40mL/min) at 503K for 2h before use. The catalyst was then transferred to a 100mL autoclave and mixed with solvent, substrate, and CD or CN. The reaction began when hydrogen (4.0MPa) was introduced into the autoclave with stirring at ambient temperature. The reaction was stopped after a proper time and the products were analyzed by GC-FID (GC-2014, Shimadzu) equipped with a chiral capillary column (HP19091G-B213, 30m×0.32mm×0.25μm, Agilent). The optical yield for the enantioselective hydrogenation was expressed as ee value: ee (%)=([R]−[S])/([R]+[S])×100. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst The MIL-101 support and Pt/MIL-101 catalyst were first investigated by XRD and N2 adsorption–desorption measurements. The XRD pattern of MIL-101 matched well with Ref. [10] (Fig. 1 ). After the Pt nanoparticles were loaded, the XRD pattern did not show obvious diffraction peaks assignable to Pt crystals, indicating that Pt nanoparticles were highly dispersed onto the support. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of MIL-101 and Pt/MIL-101 were nearly the same (Fig. 2 ). The specific surface areas of MIL-101 and Pt/MIL-101 were 2295 and 2217m2/g, respectively. The pore sizes of Pt/MIL-101 are centered at 1.6 and 2.1nm. There was no obvious change in the specific surface area and pore size distribution after deposition of Pt nanoparticles, indicating that Pt nanoparticles would not block the pore cavity. The morphology and particle size of the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst were characterized by SEM (Fig. 3 ). The Pt/MIL-101 grains were homogeneously dispersed with irregular shapes. From the TEM images (Fig. 4a), Pt particles were highly dispersed and the particle size was uniform and centered at 1.5–2.5nm. The Pt particle size and dispersion of the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was also calculated according to the measured CO chemisorption. The average Pt particle size of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was 2.9nm with 39.4% dispersion. This result was a little larger than that obtained from the TEM image, maybe due to that some Pt nanoparticles were partly embedded into the MIL-101 matrix and cannot adsorb CO molecules. 3.2 Asymmetric hydrogenation of α-ketoesters 3.2.1 Chiral hydrogenation of ETPY with chirally modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst In order to determine the optimal reaction parameters, several solvents were first screened for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ETPY with the CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. When the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY with the CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was conducted in cyclohexane, the conversion and ee value were rather low, only obtaining 31.1% conversion and 13.3% ee value (Table 1 , entry 1). With increasing the polarity of the solvent to 0.648, the reaction performed in acetic acid went much faster, furnishing 91.3% conversion and 76.5% ee value (Table 1, entry 2). When the polarity of the solvent was further increased, the conversion of ETPY was further improved. The reaction in ethanol and in water gave 93.3% and 98.5% conversions, respectively (Table 1, entries 6 and 7). Obviously, the conversion of ETPY increased with increasing the polarity of the solvent, so that the reaction performed in water gave the highest conversion with the TOF reaching 3562h−1. The activity obtained with CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was comparable with that afforded by Pt nanoparticles entrapped in mesopolymers, which gave 3908h−1 TOF under the similar conditions [37]. However, there is a different trend for the enantioselectivity. The highest enantioselectivity of 76.5% was obtained in acetic acid (Table 1, entry 2). In the solvents with the higher polarity, medium ee values were furnished. The solubility of chiral modifier, cinchona alkaloid, increases with increasing the empirical polarity initially and reaches a maximum at a value of ∼0.6, and then decreases again with further increase in polarity [38]. Furthermore, the chiral modifier CD would be protonated in acetic acid, while the protonated CD could induce higher enantioselectivity [39]. Therefore, the highest ee value can be obtained in acetic acid for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY with CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. In order to understand the reaction well, the kinetic profile for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY with the CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst in acetic acid was investigated. As shown in Fig. 5 , both the conversion and ee value increased with reaction time gradually. At the beginning, only about 20.6% conversion with about 29.3% ee was obtained after 5min. With the reaction proceeding, the conversion and ee value were improved smoothly. About 54.0% conversion and 48.4% ee value were achieved after 15min. The reaction nearly completed after 30min, furnishing 76.5% ee value. Based on the conversion within 5min, the TOF reached 4469h−1. Besides CD, another cinchona alkaloid cinchonine (CN) was also applied to modify the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY. Compared with the CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst, the CN-modified catalyst showed inferior results, including conversion and ee, except that CN induced the product with S-configuration. For instance, the CN-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst afforded only 55.8% conversion and 35.5% ee value in acetic acid (Table 1, entry 5), much lower than that with the CD-modified catalyst under the same conditions. The CN-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst gave 41.8% conversion and 10.2% ee in water for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY (Table 1, entry 8). Taking into account that the highest conversion was achieved in water, while the best enantioselectivity was furnished in acetic acid, we investigated the asymmetric hydrogenation of ETPY in mixed solvents containing water and acetic acid with different volume ratios (Fig. 6 ). When acetic acid was diluted by water, the conversion of ETPY increased with increasing water amount. However, the ee values decreased with increasing water amount in the mixed solvents. This result was in accordance with many published results that chiral modifier CD and acetic acid was a good combination to afford higher ee values in asymmetric hydrogenation of α-functionalized ketones [39]. Meanwhile, we also investigated the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY in mixed solvents containing acetic acid and ethanol with different volume ratios. The results were similar to those obtained in the mixtures of acetic acid and water. As displayed in Fig. 7 , the conversions were higher in the mixed solvents than that in acetic acid, while the ee values were lower in the mixed solvents. The relatively higher conversion and ee value for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY was obtained in a mixture containing 12.5mL acetic acid and 7.5mL ethanol, achieving 96.4% conversion and 74.0% ee value (also listed in Table 1, entry 9). There may be a synergistic effect between acetic acid and ethanol. We also compared the homemade Pt/MIL-101 catalyst with the commercial Pt catalysts in the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY after chirally modified with CD. In acetic acid, the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst purchased from Alfa Aesar after modification with CD showed relatively higher results, giving 96.1% conversion and 86.6% ee value (Table 1, entry 3). Another commercial Pt/Al2O3 catalyst afforded slightly lower results than the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst (Table 1, entries 4 and 11). Compared with CD-Pt/MIL-101 catalyst, the commercial Pt/C catalyst after chirally modified with CD gave comparable results for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY under the same conditions (Table 1, entry 10). 3.2.2 Chiral hydrogenation of EOPB with chirally modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst In order to broaden the substrate scope, EOPB bearing a benzene ring with relatively large molecular size was taken as the other substrate for the chiral hydrogenation of α-ketoesters with chirally modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. It has been discovered that (R)-(+)-ethyl 2-hydroxy-4-phenylbutyrate, the hydrogenation product of asymmetric hydrogenation of EOPB, can be widely used in the preparation of chiral medicine Enalapril, which then can be used in therapy of many important symptoms such as hypertension and myocardial infarction [40]. As acetic acid was already proved the better solvent for the chiral hydrogenation of ETPY, we first investigated the chiral hydrogenation of EOPB with CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst in acetic acid. The 96.6% conversion with 53.7% ee value was obtained in acetic acid, obtaining over 2000h−1 TOF (Table 2 , entry 1). When the chiral hydrogenation with CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was carried out in ethanol, mediocre results were achieved, obtaining 54.3% conversion and 20.0% ee value (Table 2, entry 3). Additionally, the chiral hydrogenation of EOPB was also tested in the mixed solvents. In the mixed solvent containing 12.5mL acetic acid and 7.5mL ethanol, the results for the chiral hydrogenation of EOPB were similar to those obtained in neat acetic acid with the CD-Pt/MIL-101 catalyst, achieving 96.8% conversion and 53.1% ee value (Table 2, entry 4). In the mixed solvent containing acetic acid and ethanol with an equal volume, the chiral hydrogenation of EOPB with the CD-Pt/MIL-101 catalyst afforded 96.5% conversion and 76.8% ee value (Table 2, entry 5). In the mixed solvent containing 16mL acetic acid and 4mL water, the similar conversion with slightly lower enantioselectivity was obtained by comparison with that in neat acetic acid (Table 2, entry 7). The enantioselectivity afforded in the mixed solvent containing acetic acid and ethanol with the equal volume was the highest one among these results. Although we cannot explain this phenomenon at this moment, the result was repeatable. When the chiral modifier CD was replaced by CN, the configuration of the product was transferred from R to S. Moreover, the CN-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst induced much lower enantioselectivities although the conversions were comparable (Table 2, entries 2 and 6). Less than 30% ee values were afforded by the CN-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. 3.2.3 Reusability of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst The reusability of the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst is also important to consider. Therefore, we investigated the reusability of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ETPY in the mixed solvent containing 12.5mL acetic acid and 7.5mL ethanol. The catalyst was washed by fresh solvent for six times before submitted to next run and the fresh chiral modifier CD was added each time before the reaction. As shown in Fig. 8 , the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst can be used at least four times without distinct loss in activity or enantioselectivity. The fresh CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst gave 90.0% conversion and 64.7% ee. In the second run, the conversion and ee value were slightly increased by about 5%. This phenomenon can be explained by reconstruction of the catalyst, which made it more suitable for the asymmetric hydrogenation. In the third and fourth runs, the conversions and ee values were maintained. The conversion decreased a little in the fifth run and the ee value was still more than 70%. The conversion and ee value further decreased in the sixth turn. To make clear why the activity was continuously decreased after the fourth run, the catalyst after used six runs was collected and characterized. The intensities of the XRD patterns of the used catalyst assignable to MIL-101 were greatly decreased when compared with those of the fresh MIL-101 (see the XRD pattern in Fig. 1). It suggests the crystallinity of MIL-101 was decreased, which was further proved by N2 adsorption–desorption results (Fig. 2). The specific surface area of the used Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was decreased to 1169m2/g, nearly a half of that for the fresh one. The pore size of the used catalyst was also enlarged to 5.1nm. The XRD patterns of the used Pt/MIL-101 catalyst also showed some platinum peaks, indicating that platinum particles aggregated more or less during the recycling processes. The TEM image of the used catalyst in Fig. 4b confirmed that Pt particle size was slightly increased and the Pt particle size distribution was centered at 2.0–3.0nm. Therefore, the decrease of the specific surface area of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was probably owing to the incomplete crystal structure of support and to the blocked pore cavity by the agglomerated platinum particles. To reveal the reason of catalyst activity decrease, the leached Pt amount in the filtrate was also detected using ICP-AES technique. To our delight, no typical Pt signal was detected, demonstrating that the leached Pt amount was below the detection limit of ICP-AES. In other words, the Pt nanoparticles could be well stabilized by MIL-101 even under the acetic conditions. Nevertheless, the weight loss of the catalyst during recovery in each run cannot be negligible, which can also result in the decrease in activity. Based on the above discussion, the decrease in activity of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst can be mainly attributed to the decreased crystallinity of the MIL-101 structure, to the enlarged Pt particle size, and to the weight loss of the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst during the recycling experiments. 4 Conclusion The 5wt.% Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was prepared via a facile impregnation method. The CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was efficient in the asymmetric hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate and ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate. For the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate with the CD-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst in acetic acid, up to 4469h−1 TOF was achieved and the highest enantioselectivity was 76.5%. With respect to the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate, the TOF reached over 2000h−1 with the highest ee value of about 76.8% in the mixed solvent containing acetic acid and ethanol with the equal volume. Of particular note is that the Pt/MIl-101 catalyst can be reused for at least four times without distinct loss in activity or enantioselectivity. coredata.dc:description: Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was prepared via a facile impregnation method and was tested for the chiral hydrogenation of α-ketoesters after chirally modified with cinchona alkaloid. The powder XRD, N2 adsorption–desorption, TEM, and CO chemisorption were employed to characterize the Pt/MIL-101 catalyst. The Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was proved effective for the asymmetric hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate and ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate after chirally modified with cinchonidine. Up to 4469h−1 TOF with 76.5% ee of (R)-(+)-ethyl lactate was obtained with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst in acetic acid. The fastest chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIl-101 catalyst took place in neat water with medium enantioselectivity. While for the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl 2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate with the cinchonidine-modified Pt/MIL-101 catalyst, over 2000h−1 TOF with 76.8% ee value was achieved in a mixed solvent containing acetic acid and ethanol with an equal volume. Of particular note is that the Pt/MIl-101 catalyst could be reused at least four times without distinct loss in activity or enantioselectivity with addition of fresh chiral modifier each time in the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate. The catalytic performance of Pt/MIL-101 catalyst was also compared for the chiral hydrogenation of ethyl pyruvate with the commercial Pt/C and Pt/Al2O3 catalysts after modification with cinchona alkaloid.
coredata.dc:title: Pt nanoparticles entrapped in mesoporous metal–organic frameworks MIL-101 as an efficient and recyclable catalyst for the asymmetric hydrogenation of α-ketoesters
